column4: Help: I installed "network manager" and cant find it's loading icon
install package "network-manager-gnome", that sets up the panel icon.
isn't that the same as installing it thru the synaptic?
there's 'network-manager', and also 'network-manager-gnome'. two different things. at least that's how it is on dapper. :)
but yea, i do mean getting it with synaptic.
even after installing network-manager-gnome (thru synaptic), I still cant find how to load it
run "nm-applet"
and to start it automatically when you log in, just add that to your session startup.
nm-applet (when run in terminal) does nothing

nothing appears in the system tray? ... strange. well, maybe it doesn't work the same way as it does on dapper (that's what i'm still running). try rebooting (yea, i know...), and if it still doesn't work, i'm probably just using outdated info.
you were right, it did show up, sorry
oh, heh, ok. makes me feel better that i'm not completely out of date. hehe.
however, this app seems to have no configuration options...
click on the icon, it will give you a menu...
it doesnt recognize my wireless adapter i think... i guess i'll look for another app
what's the output of "ifconfig"?
if ifconfig doesn't show it, then nothing will.
ifconfig recognizes it, my wireless adapter does work and this is how I installed it: https://help.ubuntu.com/community/WifiDocs/Device/Belkin_F5D7050_ver_4000_(ZyDas_zd1211b_driver)
if you want network-manager to manage your adapter, then you have to comment out any references to it in more /etc/network/interfaces
all I want is to be able to use WPA-PSK  encryption, do I really need network-manager-gnome for that?
i don't think you need it, i'm pretty sure you can run wpa without network-manager. but i don't use wpa-psk myself, so i'm out of my expertise at this point. :)
